items.synopsis: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says Shaun Drummond's decision to quit as Queensland Health director-general is his own, and that when he was appointed last October he said he would not stay for the full term.

title.children: Queensland Health boss resigns days after disagreement with minister

title.children: Inflation falls sharply, 'soft enough to see the RBA halt' rate rises

image.altText: People walking in Brisbane's Queen Street Mall

items.synopsis: The latest monthly consumer price indicator shows inflation eased sharply to 5.6 per cent over the 12 months to May, down from 6.8 per cent in April. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Future interest rate rises uncertain as inflation hits 13-month low of 5.6pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is it fair to say that, due to the increased cost of rentals, the RBA may have to increase interest rates to make housing more expensive in order to make housing more affordable? Just confirming that is the logic here? - Tim. Hi Tim, You're one of a few keen commenters who have pointed this out. It sounds counterintuitive but you're right — that is exactly the logic here. RBA governor Philip Lowe told a Senate Estimates hearing in Canberra last month that higher interest rates will help alleviate some rental pressures in the short term because it would force people to "economise" on their housing — which translates to either living at home for longer, or getting housemates. Here's what he said: "The way that this ends up fixing itself, unfortunately, is through higher housing prices and higher rents. "Because as rents go up people decide not to move out of home, or you don't have that home office, you [get] a flatmate. "The increase in supply can't happen immediately, but higher prices do lead people to economise on housing. "That's the price mechanism at work. We need more people on average to live in each dwelling, and prices do that." Rents make up a solid chunk of the consumer price index (in fact, Mr Lowe says they're the "single largest" component) and expects rents will remain high for some time. Of course, long term we need to see an increase in housing supply — which Mr Lowe also acknowledged during Estimates. You can read the full story about Mr Lowe's justification for higher rents by my colleagues Gareth Hutchens and Rhiana Whitson below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are higher interest rates making housing more expensive so it will then be more affordable?

featuredLink.title: Higher rents will help reduce rental stress by encouraging people to 'economise' on housing, RBA governor says

children.content: Is it fair to say that, due to the increased cost of rentals, the RBA may have to increase interest rates to make housing more expensive in order to make housing more affordable? Just confirming that is the logic here?
- Tim
Hi Tim,
You're one of a few keen commenters who have pointed this out. It sounds counterintuitive but you're right — that is exactly the logic here.
RBA governor Philip Lowe
told a Senate Estimates hearing in Canberra last month that higher interest rates will help alleviate some rental pressures in the short term because it would
force people to "economise" on their housing
— which translates to either living at home for longer, or getting housemates.
Here's what he said:
"The way that this ends up fixing itself, unfortunately, is through higher housing prices and higher rents.
"Because
as rents go up people decide not to move out of home, or you don't have that home office, you [get] a flatmate
"The increase in supply can't happen immediately, but
higher prices do lead people to economise on housing
"That's the price mechanism at work. We
need more people on average to live in each dwelling
, and prices do that."
Rents make up a solid chunk of the consumer price index (in fact, Mr Lowe says they're the "single largest" component) and expects rents will remain high for some time.
Of course, long term we need to see an increase in housing supply — which Mr Lowe also acknowledged during Estimates.
You can read the full story about Mr Lowe's justification for higher rents by my colleagues Gareth Hutchens and Rhiana Whitson below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Agricultural bank Rabobank thinks May's softer inflation figures could see the RBA end its interest rate rises soon. Rabobank is betting on an RBA rate rise in August, which it thinks could be the final increase by the central bank. That would bring official rates to 4.35 per cent. "Substantial cost pressures remain in rents, takeaway food prices and some grocery categories, but  overall the picture is of disinflation across a number of goods." " We therefore maintain our call that there will be just one more hike this year to reach a terminal cash rate of 4.35 per cent, and that the most  likely timing for that hike to occur is the August meeting." "This will allow the RBA to examine the  June labour force report and the second quarter CPI report before taking further action to increase the cash  rate. " "The soft monthly inflation reading for May increases our conviction that the RBA is  approaching the end of its hiking cycle."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rabobank: RBA close to end of hiking cycle

children.content: Agricultural bank Rabobank thinks May's softer inflation figures could see the RBA end its interest rate rises soon.
Rabobank is betting on an RBA rate rise in August, which it thinks could be the final increase by the central bank.
That would bring official rates to 4.35 per cent.
"Substantial cost pressures remain in rents, takeaway food prices and some grocery categories, but  overall the picture is of disinflation across a number of goods."

" We therefore maintain our call that there will be just one more hike this year to reach a terminal cash rate of 4.35 per cent, and that the most  likely timing for that hike to occur is the August meeting."
"This will allow the RBA to examine the  June labour force report and the second quarter CPI report before taking further action to increase the cash  rate. "
"The soft monthly inflation reading for May increases our conviction that the RBA is  approaching the end of its hiking cycle."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The good news is that headline inflation fell from May last year, but underlying inflation remains above 6 per cent. AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina says there is room for the Reserve Bank to pause interest rate hikes at next week's meeting. The official cash rate is currently at 4.1 per cent and some economists think it could rise to 4.85 per cent to curb inflation. Ms Mousina says prices are coming down from last year's high. "However clearly the pace of inflation is too high and well      above the RBA’s target 2-3 per cent target band." " The RBA may also be concerned      that some of the underlying inflation measures like CPI excluding volatile      items and travel was up by 6.4 per cent year on year – higher than the headline      index." " Today’s inflation data gives the Reserve Bank room to pause hiking      rates at its next meeting next Tuesday, but the high level of inflation and      the RBA’s concern about increasing wages growth will keep the RBA hawkish      and means that another 1-2 rate hikes are still likely over coming months." The market is pricing in a 30 per cent chance of a rate hike next week, but most traders expect official borrowing costs to stay on hold.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA has room to pause

children.content: The good news is that headline inflation fell from May last year, but underlying inflation remains above 6 per cent.
AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina says there is room for the Reserve Bank to pause interest rate hikes at next week's meeting.
The official cash rate is currently at 4.1 per cent and some economists think it could rise to 4.85 per cent to curb inflation.
Ms Mousina says prices are coming down from last year's high.
"However clearly the pace of inflation is too high and well      above the RBA’s target 2-3 per cent target band."

" The RBA may also be concerned      that some of the underlying inflation measures like CPI excluding volatile      items and travel was up by 6.4 per cent year on year – higher than the headline      index."

" Today’s inflation data gives the Reserve Bank room to pause hiking      rates at its next meeting next Tuesday, but the high level of inflation and      the RBA’s concern about increasing wages growth will keep the RBA hawkish      and means that another 1-2 rate hikes are still likely over coming months."
The market is pricing in a 30 per cent chance of a rate hike next week, but most traders expect official borrowing costs to stay on hold.

image.altText: A black and white graphic of the two men against a Russian map with a red semi-circle behind them.

items.synopsis: Recent developments in Russia raise serious questions about the future of President Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine. Join our live Q&A as our experts unpack your questions.

title.children: Is Putin in trouble? Join our experts to discuss the latest struggle for power inside the Kremlin

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is the future of Wagner? Comments from Putin and Belarus seem to suggest that Wagner members have the option of moving over to Belarus. Will Belarus have direct control over Wagner now or is this a sophisticated Russian trap? - Josh Hi Josh, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to our global affairs editor John Lyons, who writes: Hi Josh - I don't think we know the future of Wagner. There are many unanswered questions out of the latest drama and this is one of them. We hear reports that some Wagner fighters are angry with Prigozhin that he didn't let them know about the rebellion but it's hard to read. My view is that Prigozhin still has influence over many of them, especially if he can keep paying them. He is something of a cult-like leader to many of them. So I think the key to the future of Wagner lies with with Prigozhin does. Does he go back to Africa where he has many clients for "security services" such as Mali, and much wealth from gold and diamond mines there? Or does he sit in Belarus and watch what happens at the top of the Kremlin? I tend to think he wants to stay around and see what opportunities there are for him in Moscow.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is the future of Wagner?

children.content: What is the future of Wagner? Comments from Putin and Belarus seem to suggest that Wagner members have the option of moving over to Belarus. Will Belarus have direct control over Wagner now or is this a sophisticated Russian trap? -
Josh
Hi Josh, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to our global affairs editor
John Lyons
, who writes:

Hi Josh - I don't think we know the future of Wagner. There are many unanswered questions out of the latest drama and this is one of them. We hear reports that some Wagner fighters are angry with Prigozhin that he didn't let them know about the rebellion but it's hard to read.

My view is that Prigozhin still has influence over many of them, especially if he can keep paying them. He is something of a cult-like leader to many of them. So I think the key to the future of Wagner lies with with Prigozhin does. Does he go back to Africa where he has many clients for "security services" such as Mali, and much wealth from gold and diamond mines there? Or does he sit in Belarus and watch what happens at the top of the Kremlin? I tend to think he wants to stay around and see what opportunities there are for him in Moscow.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there a political figure or influential person in Russia who would be able to replace Putin? — Christa Hi Christa, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to our global affairs editor John Lyons who writes: Christa — intriguing question. I think the answer is it's hard to know. Because Putin is so hardline and ruthless, no-one has really wanted to show leadership qualities for fear that Putin might be threatened by them. People like Dmitry Medvedev have used the war to display their nationalist credentials, but hard to know. I think the various generals and oligarchs will be decisive in deciding who replaces Putin. Even now (because of the rebellion) I think behind the scenes there would be a lot of consideration of post-Putin scenarios, but most of this will be happening out of sight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is there anyone who could replace Putin?

children.content: Is there a political figure or influential person in Russia who would be able to replace Putin? —
Christa
Hi Christa, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to our global affairs editor
John Lyons
who writes:

Christa — intriguing question. I think the answer is it's hard to know. Because Putin is so hardline and ruthless, no-one has really wanted to show leadership qualities for fear that Putin might be threatened by them.
People like
Dmitry Medvedev

have used the war to display their nationalist credentials, but hard to know. I think the various generals and oligarchs will be decisive in deciding who replaces Putin. Even now (because of the rebellion) I think behind the scenes there would be a lot of consideration of post-Putin scenarios, but most of this will be happening out of sight.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is the likelihood that Ukraine will take the opportunity to invade Russia if Civil war breaks out in Russia? — David Hi David, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to global affairs editor John Lyons who says: Hello David — My view is that there is no chance that Ukraine would invade Russia. Ukraine's entire support from its international partners is predicated on defending itself from an illegal invasion. It's on that basis that various countries — many of the NATO countries, Australia and others — have provided support. For Ukraine to invade another country would mean it was doing the same thing that it was defending itself from and would lead to complete chaos in the region. I think if civil war breaks out in Russia, Ukraine will sit back and watch. Some Ukrainians may be relieved as it will mean that if the Russians are fighting internally then they will not be focused on attacking Ukraine.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is the likelihood now of Ukraine invading Russia?

children.content: What is the likelihood that Ukraine will take the opportunity to invade Russia if Civil war breaks out in Russia? —
David
Hi David, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to global affairs editor John Lyons who says:

Hello David — My view is that there is no chance that Ukraine would invade Russia. Ukraine's entire support from its international partners is predicated on defending itself from an illegal invasion. It's on that basis that various countries — many of the NATO countries, Australia and others — have provided support.

For Ukraine to invade another country would mean it was doing the same thing that it was defending itself from and would lead to complete chaos in the region. I think if civil war breaks out in Russia, Ukraine will sit back and watch. Some Ukrainians may be relieved as it will mean that if the Russians are fighting internally then they will not be focused on attacking Ukraine.
